title: How many complaints have been made about the state of roads in Chapeltown in the last 18 months

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
I am increasing frustrated by the delays and obfuscation of repairs to the not fit for purpose road surfaces in Chapeltown.  These have not ben fit for purpose for over a year now and they condition of the surface is now a danger to life.
Specifically, the state of Loundside, Station Road, the roundabout at the end of Station Road/Cowley Lane and the roundabout  at the junction of Loundside and Burncross Road.
Please can you supply detailed information of how may complaints/reports about these road surfaces have been made in the last 18 months.  This includes ones made directly on the Council's own portal and those reported onwards by Fix my Street.
The same issues on the A6135 are being reported week in week out so can you also provide information as to how long it has taken to address these reports/complaints from members of the public.
Yours faithfully,
Len Sims

Our investigation has been between 1/11/2022 and 10/04/2024.
• The data below shows the total number of enquiries received relating
to Cat 1 potholes (urgent defects) and general highways enquires
raised.
• We are unable to separate out any ‘Fix my Street’ enquiries as we are
unable to identify where a customer enquiry originated and so the data
includes all external and internally raised enquiries relating to
potholes.
• Customer enquiries incorporate customer complaints and service
requests.
• Alongside this, we have provided the average repair time (in days)
against the total enquiries raised.
This information has been summarised below.
The data shows the number of enquiries raised for the roads identified in
the request. Please note that there may be duplicates within the data
where we have received multiple enquiries about the same defect on site.
As we were not provided road sections, we have provided the data for the
full road length sections.
Finally, the A6135 runs from the Wicker, through Burngreave and out to
Barnsley via Chapeltown. Station Road is part of the A6135, and the data
is below. If additional data is required covering additional sections of
the A6135, can these be clarified to allow for these road sections to be
captured.
Road Name Number of Enquiries Average Time Taken to Resolve (days)
Lound Side 30 2.5
Cowley Lane 70 0.5
Station Road 249 0.2
Burncross Road 80 3.49

Dear FOI,
New response to your FOI request - How many complaints have been made about the state of roads in Chapeltown in the last 18 months
Good afternoon,
Thank you for the response which I reviewed yesterday.  Apologies for the delay in reading this, I was travelling all day yesterday.
I am rather gobsmacked by the data provided and would like to bounce this back to the responder for clarification as this does not really sit with the physical evidence on the road.
Take Station Road - in 548 days, there are 249 complaints made, averaging one complaint ever 2.2 days.  The figures also state that the average time for resolution is 0.2 days , or roughly 5 hours!  If issues are resolved within 5 hours (on average) it beggars the question, why would there be 249 of them, with an average gap of 2.2 days.  In reality, these issues were hardly ever attended to, and never swiftly, with the exception of marking them as a "clear and present danger to life", only then did we get anything done - eventually!
So the main tenant of my query as to the validity of these statistics is the question I and several other locals with whom I have been working to get something done about this area's road is as follows.  What are the criteria being used to facilitate and average resolution time of 0.2 days or roughly 5 hours??  I this opening the complaint and marking it as read?  Making a site visit to assess the complaint made and making a risk assessment for adequate corrective measures to be applied as quickly as possible?  Or is it making a full and proper risk assessment and works carried out and completed?
Many locals have been dismayed for over a year at the lack of attention to repairs on this main road A6135.  So with seeing 249 complaints and next to no action during this time, I require them to pass on these criteria.
Finally, I also need to be made aware of who is responsible for signing off on either why works do not get actioned, or in the case of repairs, who signs off on the quality of these works - is it the workers themselves (that's OK, that'll do), an Amey supervisor, or a member of the council's own staff whose role it is to supervise and quality control these works?
I very much look forward to seeing a response within 28 days.
Thank you very much indeed for your assistance and attention.
Yours sincerely,
Len Sims

Dear FOI,
Thank you for your email.
What I am now seeking, is what on earth is meant in the original material supplied when mention of the 249 complaints made over 18 months regarding the set of the Station Road in Chapeltown, the A6135 road.
The 249 complaint made, it is said had an average resolution time of 0.2 days.  What dies resolution mean in this context.  Clearly by the number of complaints made over such a long time, this did not mean fixing the source of the complaint, so what did it mean??
Was it nearly opening the email and discarding the issue, or was there an onsite visit.  How is responsible for seeing that these complaints are PROPERLY investigated.
If onsite visits, how often.  Now remember, this surface was laid 6 or 7 years before the complaints began flooding in.  My final question at present is what is the expected designed life span, on a main A road, in this case, A6135 before it starts to fall apart?
Yours sincerely,
Len Sims

Dear FOI,
I appreciate the response, however, much of this is word soup and does not try to answer the questions as asked.
1. -  I appreciate that multiple complains/comments may be made about a single defect on a road.  I still fail to see how the average resolution time on the A6135 - Station Road, in Chapeltown can be 0.2 days, whilst other figures given in the original request were in the several days.
2 - I cannot believe that there is no required length of life for a capital investment scheme such as a road surface, if there is not that is poor a poor contract for the general public. I take the point that wear rates vary as you correctly state, but the MUST be some level of minimum life span.  Whether this be 1 week, a year, 6 years, a decade etc.   As a contractor, Amey has two masters to serve, the organsiation issuing the contract, ultimately SSC and it's own shareholders.  How sort a leash are the contractors kept on by SSC?
3 - I have been informed after a direct complaint to Amey, that the roundabout in the centre of Chapeltown has been earmarked for 'maintenance' .  The surface is frankly a disgrace and has not been fit for purpose for more than 3 years now.  A large circular gouge opened up at the seam between two strips of the tarmac which I complained about for about a year before it was filled.  Resembling a tram line in width, it was causing accidents.  Its was eventually filled.  Now, that infill if the best part of the surface.  I know of at least one lady who was brought off her bike by a new hole that opened up over two. months ago.  The rest of the surface is la cart track.  One of the operations executives, Mr Lawrence, sent this
"Having liaised with Michelle, I can confirm that the roundabouts in Chapeltown have been included in the schedule for resurfacing before March 2025, although we do expect this to be completed this calendar year, however, our contractual requirement allows us up to March 2025 to complete these works."
Just how dangerous does an A road need to be before urgent action is taken.
I would appreciate  answers to these queries please.
Yours sincerely,
Len Sims
